title: Detection of LLM-Generated Java Code Using Discretized Nested Bigrams
author: Timothy Paek (Syracuse University), Chilukuri Mohan (Syracuse University), ...
relevance_why: The methods for detecting code generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) may inform techniques for enhancing automatic audio generation or restoration tasks, particularly in code implementations.
background: Identifying whether code fragments are generated by an LLM or written by a human, using stylometric features and binary classification techniques.
contribution: This paper introduces Discretized Nested Bigram Frequency features and a binary classification framework to distinguish between LLM-generated and human-written Java code, achieving accuracy exceeding 96%.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically focused on detecting entire files and used simpler metrics that did not differentiate between multiple authors involved or specific snippets crafted by LLMs.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves the detection accuracy by using discretized feature sets and a classification model specifically tailored for Java code snippets.

key_innovation: Employs feature discretization to reduce sparsity and improve classification accuracy for detecting LLM-generated code.
real_world_impact: This research addresses growing concerns around academic integrity and cybersecurity by providing robust detection tools for LLM-generated code, potentially influencing educational assessments and software development practices.
limitations: The generalizability of the approach across different coding languages and styles may be limited, and further evaluation is needed on unseen LLM outputs.

new_terms.Discretized Nested Bigrams: **Discretized Nested Bigrams** refer to a feature extraction technique that aggregates and simplifies token pairs from nested code structures in a way that retains useful information while reducing dimensionality.

open_sourcing: Datasets created for the experiments are publicly available on GitHub.
